Vim Reboot 3

Line Numbers

By default vim doesn’t show line numbers. I prefer having this as it can make finding the source of exceptions slightly easier, and you waste less time by telling the person you’re pairing with to go to line 12 instead of pointing at their monitor like an ape.

    set number

Whitespace

This section is pretty self-explanatory; it tells vim how to deal with whitespace.

    set nowrap

    set tabstop=2
    set shiftwidth=2
    set softtabstop=2
    set expandtab
    set autoindent
    set smartindent

nowrap tells vim not to wrap long lines of code.

tabstop tells vim how many columns a tab counts for. Most of the work I do is in ruby, and the standard there is 2 spaces.

shiftwidth tells vim how many columns text is re-indented with when doing « and ».

softabstop controls how many columns vim uses when you hit the tab key.

expandtab tells vim to use the appropriate number of spaces to insert when hitting tab.

Find the last few settings a little confusing? Check out this site for little bit better explanation. At work, we use PHP, and our standard is 4 spaces of indentation instead of 2. You can override these settings on a per file type basis by creating a filetype.vim in ~/.vim/after/ftplugin. For example, I have a php.vim file with the following:

    setlocal tabstop=4
    setlocal shiftwidth=4
    setlocal tabstop=4

autoindent simply copies the indentation of the previous line when starting a new one.

smartindent automatically inserts one extra level of indentation in certain cases.

There is one last thing I like to do that picked up from the Janus vim configuration: 


    set list listchars=tab:\ \ ,trail:·

This tells vim to put a trailing character, · in place of any trailing whitespace. Again, this is more of a personal preference. I tend to be pretty obsseive about leaving my code and commits looking pretty.
